item.title: German Charged in Attack on Mayoral Candidate Over Refugee Work
item.description: The man faces charges of attempted murder and dangerous bodily harm for the Oct. 17 stabbing, which severely injured Henriette Reker and wounded four others.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:credit: Oliver Berg/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Henriette Reker while campaigning for mayor in Cologne, Germany, this month, a day before she was attacked.

item.title: Statues Placed in South Korea Honor ‘Comfort Women’ Enslaved for Japan’s Troops
item.description: While the creators said the timing was coincidental, the unveiling came just days before the arrival in Seoul of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Lee Yong-soo, left, who said she was forced into sexual slavery during World War II, during a rally in Seoul, South Korea, on Wednesday.

item.title: Austria Weighs Building Border Fence to Stem Flow of Migrants
item.description: With as many as 8,000 migrants entering the country each day recently, Vienna is looking into building a “technical barrier” along its frontier with Slovenia.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY, BARBARA SURK and ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Migrants in Sentilj, Slovenia, waited to cross into Austria on Tuesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Some Chinese Take Aim at Meat Industry After W.H.O. Report on Cancer Risks
item.description: Many online comments have directed their scorn not at the report that may deprive them of their favorite foods, but at the domestic food industry in China.
item.category: International Agency for Research on Cancer
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman buying meat from a butcher in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou.

item.title: Alassane Ouattara Is Re-elected President of Ivory Coast
item.description: The provisional results, announced by the Independent Electoral Commission, declared Mr. Ouattara the winner, with 83.7 percent of the vote.
item.dc:creator: SASKIA DE ROTHSCHILD
item.media:description: President Alassane Ouattara of Ivory Coast, center, after voting in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, on Sunday. Mr. Ouattara was re-elected with 83.7 percent of votes.

item.title: Distinguishing Minors From Adults in a Tide of Young Migrants
item.description: One of the biggest challenges for Germany in processing teenage migrants is to determine whether they are minors, as their legal situation changes radically on their 18th birthday.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: In Waves of Migrants, Children Arrive Alone and Settle In Uneasily
item.description: Many of Europe’s new mystery children are boys ages 14 to 17, sent by families too poor to pay smugglers for more than one journey. Others were separated from their parents along the way.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghan and Syrian youths in a painting class this month at a center in Passau, Germany. The center hosts unaccompanied teenage migrants.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe Turns Down Confucius Peace Prize
item.description: A Zimbabwean news organization reported that Mr. Mugabe decided to reject the prize after learning that it had nothing to do with the Chinese government.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Tony Abbott, Ousted Australian Leader, Urges Europe to Take Hard Line on Migrants
item.description: In a speech in London, Mr. Abbott offered Australia’s tough policies as a model. “This means turning boats around, for people coming by sea,” he said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Tony Abbott, the former prime minister of Australia, backed an aggressive policy on migration during his two years in office.

item.title: Iran Is Invited to Join U.S., Russia and Europe for Talks on Syria’s Future
item.description: If Iran agrees to attend the meeting in Vienna this week, it will be the first time Secretary of State John Kerry will enter formal negotiations with Tehran since the nuclear accord reached in July.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: World Briefing: Ivory Coast: Early Tally Shows President Poised for Win
item.description: President Alassane Ouattara was set to claim a landslide victory Wednesday after results of weekend voting were released in 19 of 31 regions.
item.dc:creator: SASKIA DE ROTHSCHILD

item.title: World Briefing: Poland: Party’s Total Is Enough to Avoid a Coalition
item.description: The right-wing and anti-migrant Law and Justice party has won a majority of seats in Poland’s Parliament and can govern alone.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Doctors Without Borders Says Yemen Hospital Is Destroyed
item.description: The site was struck multiple times by warplanes belonging to the military coalition led by Saudi Arabia, forcing evacuations, the group said.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: World Briefing: Honduras: Tiempo Newspaper Closes Amid Owners’ Graft Case
item.description: The Honduran government seized businesses belonging to the paper’s owners, whom the United States has accused of money laundering.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Man Is Sentenced in Plan to Arm Libyans
item.description: The man, Abdurraouf Eshati, 29, had been linked to a planned $28.5 million deal to send 1,100 tons of ammunition to Libya via Italy.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Mexico Moves to Scale Back a Successful Tax on Soda
item.description: Two years ago, the Mexican government imposed a tax of about 10 percent on sugary drinks. Now, legislators are trying to roll it back, angering public health experts.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Cruz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soft drinks are ubiquitous in Mexicans' diet, from streetside taco vendors to upscale restaurants. Health officials say this has contributed to the obesity epidemic in the country, where more than 70 percent of adults are overweight.

item.title: Balkans Reel as Number of Migrants Hits Record
item.description: Fresh fighting in Syria and growing fears of border closings are pushing record numbers to undertake a treacherous trek.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.dc:creator: BARBARA SURK and RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asylum seekers last week on their way to a registration camp in Dobova, Slovenia. In the past 10 days, 83,600 migrants have crossed into the country.

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: Officers Are Killed in Downing of Helicopter
item.description: A spokesman for the Tripoli government’s chief of staff said the helicopter was hit by antiaircraft fire and crashed into the sea.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Stakes Rise in Standoff Between Catalan Separatists and Spanish Government
item.description: Catalonia’s main separatist parties on Tuesday announced a new push for independence. The plan was swiftly denounced by Spain’s prime minister, Mariano Rajoy.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: U.N. Rights Investigator Highly Critical of Iran
item.description: A special investigator documented a record rate of executions, a deeply flawed judiciary system and repression of journalists, dissidents and women.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
